contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=May 2010}} {{korean name|Yun}} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul = 윤정옥 |hanja = 尹貞玉 |rr= Yun Jeong-ok |mr= Yun Chŏngok }} '''Yun Chung-Ok''' is a [[Korea]]n [[scholar]] and [[activist]] whose investigations into [[Japan]]ese [[war]] [[slavery]] during [[World War II]] led to the creation of The [[Korea]]n Council for the Women Drafted for Military Slavery by Japan. Working with two other members of the group Korea Church Women United, Kim Hye Won and Kim Sin Sil, Yun created and conducted the "Military Sexual Slavery by Japan on-the-Spot Survey". Yun frequently quoted from "Military Comfort woman" written by [[Kakou Senda]] as "200,000 Korean women were forced to be sex slave", however Senda wrote "200,000 women were forced to work for military factory, and 50,000～70,000 women out of them were forced to be Comfort Women." Yun also quoted from Senda as "200,000 Korean women forced to be Military Comfort Woman", however Senda wrote "50,000～70,000 women were Korean out of 200,000 women forced to work for military factory." Professor Yun was also an English professor at Ewha Women's University.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/03/117_62356.html|title=Korean Soldiers, Comfort Women Drafted for Japan's WWII...|date=14 March 2010|work=[[Korea Times]]|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> Her studies focused on 19th century British novels. ==See also== *[[Yasuji Kaneko]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> |name= Yun, Chung-Ok |alternative names= |short description= Korean academic |date of birth= |place of birth= |date of death= |place of death= }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yun, Chung-Ok}} [[Category:South Korean academics]] [[Category:South Korean activists]] [[Category:Anti-Japanese sentiment in Korea]] [[Category:Comfort women]] [[Category:Living people]] {{korea-academic-bio-stub}} {{korea-activist-stub}}
